151292381.review:
[h1]Inspiring Epic Work[/h1]
As I have played this guys for lots of hours, I really wanna do a review here. I will analyse the [b]Ori and Blind Forest[/b] from four aspects.
[table]
    [tr]
        [th]Project[/th]
        [th]Score[/th]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]Plot[/td]
        [td]9.0/10[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]Music[/td]
        [td]9.5/10[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]Operation[/td]
        [td]8.5/10[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]Layout[/td]
        [td]9.0/10[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]Overall[/td]
        [td]36/4 = 9/10[/td]
    [/tr]
[/table]
[b]Plot[/b]
A beautiful and perfect setting with a lovely and meaningful story behind it. I love the profound reflections behind this story on the meaning of protecting nature.

[b]Music[/b]
I guess I have listened its soundtrack for the whole year already, the soundtrack is the highlight of this game, very epic, and the BGM selected for different zones is very in line with theirs plot, environment and personality, as well as the adventure. This is commendable. My most favorite one is "Ginso Tree Escape" and this is also where I played the most. Love it. 9.5 points.

[b]Operating[/b]
First of all, it is recommended to operate the controller. It is difficult to achieve lots of actions and a comfortable experience for keyboard operation, so this is a game on the game pad. But there one I am not quite into it is the run-jump. It sometimes makes you feel whether you can reach to the stage or not with great uncertainty. But apart from this, the operation is overall good. 

[b]Layout[/b]
Throughout the game, it is not difficult but quite challenging which brings the vivid layout for this game. Some parts of the world, though you will not get through it if you encounter at the first time, with practice and time, you definitely will pass and enjoy it. And as an achievement player, I have obtained all the achievements already and felt really satisfied. Overall, 9 points.

[b]Conclusion[/b]
I give a rating of 9, which is also in line with the statistics close to the current Steam praise rate. This game is Epic and wonderful. I [b]recommend this game to anyone who should have a try tho.[/b] The deeper and more detailed you play, the better experience and the endless fun you will have.

149150142.review:
A platforming-centric metroidvania with the worst combat I have ever experienced.

Pros
-The artwork is phenomenal.
-The bash mechanic.

Cons
-The combat is miserable. Mash X to fire glowing blobs while enemies try to ram you or fire their own glowing blobs back (some of the enemies are basically just glowing blobs).
-Visual clarity is awful. So many enemies, items, and attacks in this game are glowing blobs that things can get confusing pretty quickly in combat. Also, sometimes the background/environmental art gets in the way of gameplay.
-The story loses any sense of weight once resurrection gets involved.
-Their is no fast travel mechanic so if you want to go around the map and get all the secrets you missed/were unable to get earlier you need to walk there.
-No save points in the chase sequences (this is addressed in the definitive edition).
-The mist woods as an area is kind of a pain in the ass.
-Can't disable help/tool-tip popups (reminding you that you have an upgrade point, etc) and they sometimes interfere with gameplay by obscuring platforms, enemies, etc.

Neutral
-You have a Navi but it is less annoying.

147337322.review:
[b]My review to Ori and the Blind Forest[/b]

Quote: "The forest of Nibel is dying. After a violent storm sets in motion a series of devastating events, an unassuming hero must go forth, find his courage and face a sinister threat to save his home. "Ori and the Blind Forest" tells the story of a young orphan whose destiny is pure heroism with a visually compelling action platformer created by Moon Studios for the PC. With hand-drawn graphics, meticulously animated characters and an orchestral soundtrack, "Ori and the Blind Forest" takes you through a very emotional story about love and sacrifice - and about the hope that lives in all of us."

[u][b]Pro:[/b][/u]
+ 50 Steam-achievements
+ Steam Trading Cards
+ Full controller support
+ Remote Play on TV
+ Steam Deck Compatibility verified
+ Very beautiful and atmospheric story
+ Fantastic soundtrack and music

[u][b]Contra:[/b][/u]
- Some achievements were a bit more annoying to pick up
- In some places it is a bit frustrating

[h1]I definitely recommend this game![/h1]

145749416.review:
I adore this game with all my heart!
 
I died 3000+ times in one run that clocked in at just under 33 hours total. My typical pattern went like this: I attempted to pass a section, died dozens of times, rage quit, went back to try again this time with the help of  tutorials (hail the almighty tutorials), passed the section after another dozen upon dozen of tries and began the cycle again. All that being said, I think it speaks to the beauty, challenge and pure FUN of this game that I kept coming back again and again with a smile on my face when I finally got it. It is not an easy game by any means, but I love that it isn't! 

I don't play games like this often and this was my first true 'requires building skill if you want to get anywhere' game. I feel so accomplished and happy after finishing. I applaud the team for all of your hard work! I've 100% cursed your name more than once (and during the life tree, valley of the wind and the final escape contemplated how much of a sadist you have to be to make this XD )

Did it take me 32+ hours to finish one file, yes. Did I die countless times and get unspeakably frustrated to the point of physically walking away, yes. Did I have one of the best gaming experiences I've ever had, absolutely! I recommend this game to anyone looking for a challenge partnered with a gorgeous soundtrack (seriously give your soundtrack team a raise!) stunning visuals and effects. 

Thank you for this amazing game! Once I've emotionally recovered from the sheer stress of being hunted through a fiery landscape of doom that I could not stop to blink in? I'll definitely be playing again! (I'm hoping to get my death total down to 2000 this next round! )

144096123.review:
★★☆☆☆ Okay!

[h1]Puzzle[/h1]

The beginning of this game is nice and atmospheric, despite there not being clear enough indications of when you can play and when you are watching a rendered video and the characters moving super slow in some scenes which is really annoying.

However, the gameplay itself is quite tedious. Basically, it's a large click fest. The enemies in this game are quite strong and Ori is kind of weak so most of the time you'll find yourself awkwardly trying to dodge enemy projectiles or attacks (which can often 2-shot you or even 1-shot you no matter how large your health is) while clicking like a madman in order to damage them with your flame. This game is way too much focused on combat (which is not very well done, to make matters worse) rather than exploring which is the best portion of the game and definitely fulfills its role, as returning to areas and finding new items and powers are the best parts of this game.

So, to sum it up, this game tries to play on visual and atmospheric side in order to hide the fact that the gameplay is full of quite strange designer choices that make the game quite a chore to play as opposed to a fun ride.

Nice music and visuals, but a poor story and no real lore!

The "Light" acted irresponsible, and killed three of four children of the "Dark". Understandably pissed the "Dark" destroyed the "Light". If I could, I would've joined the owl and help her collect and destroy all leftover pieces of light. Would be basically the same game, only you don't have to do those stupid-a*s "Boss-fights".

142319810.review:
I can't believe I never reviewed this game until now. I was blown away by Ori, which happened to be my first platformer. I definitely struggled quite a bit at first, and with one spot in particular, but that only strengthened my love for this game (and game style). I never felt like the controls were clunky or difficult to use. The system for energy and health is great as are the power-ups. Really, I have no complaints. 

Then we have the graphics. I have never been so impressed by a game's design than I have with Ori. The fact that it's hand-painted just blows my mind. 

And then, of course, the story. I'm a crier, but I haven't cried during video games before. That changed with this one. It was such a good, emotional story about perseverance and the strong bonds of familial love. 

10000000/10 - If you're unsure about this one, get it.

140194541.review: what to say about ori and the blind forest...this game is..intricate. intricate in the sense that it's a rage game disguised as a survival game disguised as a puzzle platformer that tries to distract you with pretty visuals. this game is good in sense of atmosphere, visuals, sound design, storyline all that jazz. where this game lacks is in the game play itself. for one, the save system is awful. in the game you have a bunch of different energy bars that act as resources in the game (this is largely where the survival element comes in) one of those is your "spirit energy" what you're able to do with this is open doors, perform special attacks and also save the game which allows you to save your progress in real time. pretty cool right? W R O N G. the game's design is literally so ungodly difficult which combined with a very much problematic lack of energy pickups makes saving a near constant necessity to make any progress whatsoever. this is due to the game basically not having a checkpoint system; it will literally reset all of your progress if you don't save every 2 seconds. this gets rather annoying because EVERYTHING will kill you. touch a thorn? all your health vanishes faster than haitian relief funds at the clinton foundation. too many projectiles clogging up where you can go? your health drops faster than my credit score. simply touch a slime on accident? it's like watching a mexican kid get slapped by a sandal, that little sucker loses a chunk of his soul. when this game gets into the late stages of the story, things get (even more) difficult. your brain has to operate like the gpu for the james webb telescope. basic accomplishments require millions of tiny micro-adjustments to the point where if people could see what im doing with my hands playing this game i might just get a girlfriend. one last note; I actually really hate the skill trees in this game. you kill so many enemies and get very little xp for each and with different skills having different costs and even prerequisites it gets very expensive to make a noticeable change. word of advice though: max out the blue and purple trees first as those are the ones that allow you to survive long enough to make a save. getting skills barely improves anything and finding things like life cells (pickups that increase your max health because yeah it's not your skill points that do that it's a bunch of hidden pickups strategically placed around the map so you have to repetitively die to learn how to get one) and energy cells (which virtually don't exist) is tedious at best. pls collect my spirit energy

139640868.review:
I just completed "Ori and the Blind Forest".  What a beautiful game!  The music, art, and story were an endearing accompaniment to a creative and challenging 2D puzzle platformer in the vein of "Metroid".  

The generous save states ensure that the game doesn't become too frustrating by allowing you to frequently create your own checkpoints to break down tricky puzzles (and there are plenty of these!) into more manageable pieces for trial and error.

My only complaint is that there isn't more of it!  The game is fairly brief, although there is some additional value for completionists who wish to go back and explore every inch of the world by using their new-found skills to access the previously inaccessible.

There are also multiple difficulty modes including a one-life mode for the masochists.  But be warned!  While "easy" mode adjusts damage taken by enemies and the like, it doesn't seem to otherwise affect the challenging platforming and puzzle elements that comprise the meat of this game.  So, if you were considering this game for the cute story, art, and music and platforming isn't really your thing, "Ori" might be a poor choice!

Also, if you were expecting a game with a lot of combat-oriented challenges, this is not it.  Ori is not a fighter.  Enemies serve as obstacles or pieces in the many puzzles you'll encounter.  Instead of epic boss battles, you'll find thrilling escape sequences featuring challenging platforming under time pressure.  

The first of which, the "Ginso Tree Escape" is one of the most fun and memorable such challenges I've ever experienced, in fact!  It introduces a clever mechanic unique to "Ori" (as far as I'm aware?) and wastes no time in getting you acquainted with it!

I was looking for a Metroid-like 2D platformer and "Ori" didn't disappoint!  If this style of game is your thing, this one is not to be missed! It's absolutely adorable, fun, but also quite challenging.  10/10

138157907.review:
I think I came up with a pretty good test for detecting a psychopath. All you need to is:

- Chain someone to your gaming chair;
- Make them play first ten minutes of Ori and the Blind Forest;
- Listen to any "awwww" sounds. 

Seriously, this game is so awwww-some that I don't think most human beings have a capacity to withhold such overwhelming cuteness, unless something is terribly wrong with them. Going through Ori's intro sequence is like watching a duckling that falls to sleep next to a bunch of small kittens. This game enchants you quickly, sucks you into its world in a matter of seconds and just like someone who failed the aforementioned test, it will never let you forget it.

In case it wasn't obvious before and by some miracle you've missed all the screenshots, I'll state the obvious: it's a TRULY BEAUTIFUL GAME. Vividly drawn landscapes and happy fluid animations are parts of its charm, but combined with an ABSOLUTELY GENIUS SOUNDTRACK create a true feast for the senses; one that will only be depreciated by inventing edible strawberry-flavored monitors. The simple act of just pacing around is a great audio-visual experience, but along with the looks comes a surprisingly well-written story, giving our movements a deeper purpose. Despite its simplicity and Disneyesque qualities, it's told quite well, shifting the moods along the ride. While Ori is generally a joyful experience, it can also be full of tension or filled with grim solemnity. Each area has its own mood, making the world feel incredibly alive.

Game's great atmosphere and soothing colors are important for other reasons, namely calming us down. Ori has a QUITE HIGH DIFFICULTY LEVEL, that's usually somewhere between "that's gonna be a challenge" and "Oh, hell no". The whole game area is one giant level, divided into smaller areas, creating something that gaming PhDs would call "Metroidvania-inspired platformer". While at first the road ahead is quite easy and straightforward, Ori quickly learns a bunch of new abilities that broaden the area of exploration to the size of New Caledonia. Curiosity and good eyes are often rewarded with the additional XP and power-ups, so there's a good reason to stray often from our path, but it's also incredibly easy to get lost in the huge sprawling environment. And sometimes you're going to waste time trying to beat a challenge that looks do-able, but it can only be done with certain skills that you don't yet possess. Some sections are just also old-fashionably hard, especially when you had the misfortune of saving the game with a low amount of health. When you painstakingly try to make your way through the level for the 20th time even the beauty of the world around can be lost. 

Despite giving us a harsh time now and then, Ori and the Blind Forest remains a PHENOMENAL game. The definitive edition is probably the best way to start the adventure with it, since it offers more content, new abilities, option to adjust difficulty and various quality of life improvements, etc., but you still won't be disappointed by going for the original version. It is still one of the best games I had the pleasure of playing and after 200 titles I'm not stating this lightly. It's an incredible experience and a total must-play. 10/10. My thumb is up so high that I'm going to look like a Statue of Liberty on this one!

137551056.review:
I very, very rarely review games, so I'm doing this out of sheer respect and thankfulness for the developer, Moon Studios.

Ori is easily one of the best games I have bought on a whim (in 8 years of Steam), and had I had any idea of that... well, it wouldn't have been on a whim. The art is probably what stands out the most, but that's only because the controls are so well implemented, they never really took me out of this immersive - and touching - story. Not for a second, honestly.

It was sufficiently challenging for me as a seasoned gamer, but I'm more than sure it shouldn't be frustrating for any casual gamer who doesn't possess a really, really short temper. In fact, I cannot think of another game that made me care so little about dying and having to repeat the same difficult scenes. To the opposite: I was so excited by them (in no small part thanks to the amazing soundtrack and artwork that surely accompanied), that I sometimes died on purpose at the end of a tough part to try to play it again more perfectly. I feel like this is a really big deal and I hope you believe me.

I can honestly think of only one con: you cannot (as of yet at least) continue playing your save after you finish the game. I wish I had known this before, because I truly wanted to go back and finish it 100% - something I'm not at all used to - but I'm sure I'll play through it again. By the way, I makes me happy that the Ori has TEN different slots for you and your family/friends to start a game on. I don't understand why so many games lack that.

In short, I HIGHLY recommend playing Ori, and I can see no contraindications to warn buyers of. Gameplay, art and soundtrack are truly remarkable, and the story is surprising and nothing short of beautiful. This is a game that stands out, and one to remember for a long, long time. Thank you and congratulations to the developers for making such a brilliant game, and selling it for such fair price.

I'll finish by quoting another reviewer: "Oh how I wish there were more games like this one, especially when they come out of nowhere like this one did."

One of the best things I've played.

Ori and the Blind Forest is a visually stunning game that is sure to captivate players from start to finish. The game's art style is simply breathtaking, with lush environments and intricate character designs that are full of detail and personality.

But the game's beauty is not just skin deep. The gameplay is equally impressive, featuring a combination of platforming challenges, puzzle-solving, and combat that is both engaging and rewarding. The controls are tight and responsive, allowing players to execute complex maneuvers with ease.

One of the things that makes Ori and the Blind Forest so special is its emotional depth. The game's story is beautifully told, with a powerful message about the importance of love and sacrifice. The game's score is also exceptional, with a hauntingly beautiful soundtrack that perfectly complements the game's themes and visuals.

Another standout feature of Ori and the Blind Forest is its level design. Each area is meticulously crafted, with a careful balance of platforming challenges, combat encounters, and puzzle-solving that keeps the gameplay fresh and engaging throughout the entire experience.

Overall, Ori and the Blind Forest is an exceptional game that deserves all of the praise it has received. Its stunning visuals, engaging gameplay, and emotional depth make it a must-play for any fan of the platformer genre. If you're looking for a game that will take your breath away and tug at your heartstrings, Ori and the Blind Forest is definitely worth checking out.

Ori and the Blind Forest is an interesting case. In a vacuum, the game is very entertaining. Great art style, beautiful music, fun level-design. 
But Ori and the Will of the Wisps exists. Because of how much better Ori 2 is, I find it hard to recommend Ori 1. Ori 1 has some great features, but also some annoying parts of gameplay and an overall quick story makes the game forgettable in comparison. 
If you want about 5-10 hours of entertainment, Ori and the Blind Forest ain't bad at all, but if you want to spend more time (and have higher replay value), just go for Ori and the Will of the Wisps; it does everything Ori 1 does but better, fixes major issues, and adds a lot more interesting mechanics and gameplay.

135718276.review:
[h1] Esto no es una reseña, es una review... [/h1]

[b] Uno de los mejores exponentes de un género [/b]

Muy a mi pesar, postergue demasiado esta obra, y es que me he estado perdiendo de uno de los mejores títulos del que se ha convertido en uno de mis géneros favoritos de los videojuegos, y es que Ori and the Blind Forest sabe llevar la formula Metroidvania a un nivel excelso mediante un trayecto que resulta muy... efímero. El juego es muy corto, mas en tan poco tiempo ha sabido llegarle al jugador con un gameplay sólido, y una historia que aunque demuestre simpleza, es extremadamente funcional para este ambiente.

Ori and the Blind Forest es probablemente el juego en 2 dimensiones más magnífico que he tenido el honor de presenciar, no existe una sola zona, paisaje o recoveco en donde no se note el mimo que le han puesto al crear este juego, la cantidad de capas que posee el fondo es sencillamente deslumbrante, incluso me atrevería a decir que es de lo mas hermoso que he contemplado no solo a nivel de juegos en 2 dimensiones, sino en toda la historia de los videojuegos. Y a pesar de que en CONTADAS ocasiones Ori puede tener problemas visuales al no ser capaces de distinguir entre el terreno que el juego posee y el fondo de un paisaje, no es nada que considero se le pueda reprender.

En Moon Studios han encontrado un equilibrio casi perfecto entre secciones de plataformeo y de combate, estando prácticamente combinadas la una con la otra, permitiéndonos a la vez vislumbrar la preciosura que se encuentra fuera del foco principal del juego al ponernos una interfaz súper simple y poco molesta que nada cubre de la pantalla, ya que Ori sabe que su punto álgido no son sus controles ni su cándido sistema de lucha, sino como su apartado audiovisual se acopla a lo susodicho, Ori es, sencillamente, una coreografía que tiene al espectador bailando al son que él desea, cuando lo desea. 

Y es por ello que en Moon Studios no quisieron hacer de su juego un desafío, sino un viaje, y vaya que lo lograron; si bien soy consciente de que la Definitive Edition tiene mejoras como el buen uso de los estanques como puntos de teletransportación, no me ha gustado nada que le hayan agregado niveles de dificultad a un título que no lo necesitaba, ya que precisamente eso es lo que un desafío es, y no un viaje; esto lo menciono habiendo vivenciado de primera mano la dificultad difícil, la cual honestamente creo cambia radicalmente la experiencia que el juego quiere ofrecer, uno de los puntos más fuertes de Ori es su simpleza, que con tan poco, tanto logra.

Otra mecánica que posee Ori muy bien implementada, es su árbol de habilidades, el cual si bien no es muy variado, contiene lo suficiente como para fomentar la exploración y a la vez hacerte sentir una sensación de progreso digna de un Metroidvania, ya que Ori sabe perfectamente dónde y cuándo otorgarte las habilidades de su repertorio, y sabe explotarlas al máximo. Es alucinante como es capaz de cambiar tan drásticamente el ritmo y la sensación tanto de movimiento como de exploración con tan solo una nueva habilidad o alteración en el mapa, y es que en este aspecto, Ori es el mejor ejemplo de lo que "progreso" debería significar en un videojuego.

[spoiler] Si bien es cierto que el punto fuerte de Ori es su sencillez a la hora de narrarnos toda una experiencia, siendo el objetivo del juego conmovernos, lo cual logra con creces... y a la vez no. La historia de Ori fácilmente se trata de una especie de... ¿perro? que resulta ser la esencia del Árbol de Espíritu, y al Ori desentonarse de dicho árbol, el bosque se fue a la ruina, para recuperar a Ori el árbol emitió una luz que era mortal para los Búhos, lo que nos lleva a nuestro antagonista, Kuro, quien solo quería proteger a sus crías, al fallar en el intento estorbando a nuestro protagonista, cegada por el odio su único objetivo en mente es acabar con Ori, echándose atrás al ver que el "padre adoptivo" de Ori le demostraba el mismo cariño que ella a sus crías.....
Suena a que tuvieron que acortar su historia para que quepa dentro de la duración del juego, y que no se me malinterprete, la historia si funciona muy bien acoplado de la maravila visual y la inigualable banda sonora que el juego tiene, simplemente dicho desenlace no se siente... apropiado, es forzado, y aunque se nota que quisieron hacerlo de forma que tocara el corazón del jugador, en mi caso, no lo lograron de esa forma, al menos no mediante su narrativa, ya que todos sus otros ámbitos me llegan al alma, sobre todo en sus momentos de auge cuando el reloj esta sonando mientras que has de moverte a toda prisa y de fondo suena una pista que a cualquiera fascinaría. [/spoiler]

A día de hoy, comprendo por que este juego es en cierta medida, la "competencia" del que es mi juego favorito y el que creo posee el título de mejor Metroidvania existente, Hollow Knight. Independientemente de que crea imposible para Ori superarlo, si lo considero como una entrada excelente al género, y en definitiva una de las mejores experiencias audiovisuales que difícilmente alguien podría olvidar.

135492008.review: Ori has beautiful graphics, a moving soundtrack, and a compelling story-- but the gameplay is severely lacking. I realize that this is a platformer, but the combat is uncontrollable and random: you cannot aim at a particular target, other than by being in its vicinity, and there is no skill to it: it is literally button mashing. The platforming aspects do little to make up for this, as the jump (particularly the wall jump) is frustrating and sometimes does not register clicks, and the double and wall jumps are not consistent in their distance despite deliberately trying to repeat particular jumps with the same timing and motions. Maybe it is unfair to compare it to Hollow Knight, where the platforming was smooth and natural and consistent, but Ori just doesn't meet expectations. I can't recommend this as a fun enjoyable experience to play, although I have enjoyed watching other people stream it. If you're looking for something great to play to scratch the HK itch, this isn't it.

And I haven't seen that elsewhere. I've seen good lookin', I've seen good singin'. But ain't I ever seen a game that dose both. The hate part of this is when your playing the game for the first time the game actually over steps and thinks a tad too much of you. 134742054.review:
I feel like any time this game is brought up everyone always has to say how oh it's such a masterpiece and it's so great and really just circle jerk the hell out of it.

This game is forgettable, it has the opening sequence that seems to be the only part anyone remembers where great value Totoro dies and it's so sad I guess even though it's 3 minutes into the game. From there it's no real narrative and the scenery is never really as striking anymore, but hurr durr gotta suck off the indie title because it has an artstyle even though the game itself does everything in its power to annoy you. Gameplay itself is pretty generic, honestly it's pretty basic as far as platformers go, but it's Ori's rage inducing segments that feel out of place and really makes me wish people looked at the game more critically. In a game that should really prioritize flow of movement and making traversal feel smooth and satisfying, you frequently run into horrible sequences of obstacles that have you repeating the same segment over and over. These random difficulty spikes are jarring and feel arbitrary. Can't exactly enjoy the scenery when you want to punch a hole through your monitor. For some perspective last I played this my game got soft locked in some death loop area that made zero sense and I haven't played since. Seemingly no one remembers or acknowledges these issues with the game and it's kind of astonishing the way everyone seems to have rose tinted glasses after playing the intro. Maybe that's a testament to it's effectiveness as an opening act but I still have my reservations.

This is not an overtly bad game but it's merely serviceable, and leaves no lasting positive impression aside from it's intro sequence. The only 2 things I immediately associate with this game is Winnie the Pooh lookin ass and the frustrating gameplay. Yet Ori has always been declared as a masterpiece seemingly by default, The advertising for the sequel is a testament to this where it just feels like the devs pleasuring themselves to their creation. The marketing boils down to them just saying it's ORI again ORI is back the critically aclaimed masterpiece game of the year edition of all time ORI and then they just plaster review scores all over the place. Maybe I'm just cynical but I don't buy it, if we're going to use an accurate scale 4/10 feels fair for Ori, it's okay but it's good points really won't blow your mind or leave you with a strong lasting impression. In conclusion I'm probably gonna go throw bricks at homeless people.

Overall, Ori and the Blind Forest is a masterpiece of a game that excels in every aspect, and it's an absolute must-play for anyone who loves beautiful visuals, captivating gameplay, and emotionally resonant storytelling.

132848600.review:
Wish there were a neutral review option. Play for artistic value. In terms of gameplay/QOL, within the first hour I noticed:
-There's no quick access map
-The controls are sightly janky, movement doesn't feel particularly crisp
-Combat is just mashing X until enemies with slightly too much health are dead. Not super fun.
-Camera is naturally zoomed way out and several enemies spray tiny little balls of light as attacks. Your primary attack is little tiny balls of light. I can't dodge reliably because I can't see where the tiny, only slightly different color balls of light are going. I've completed no hit challenge content in Hollow Knight. I don't think the problem is me.
-Dying deletes all progress since the last save. Everything. XP, whether you saw a cutscene, etc. Like it never happened. There are also a myriad of instant death mechanics. This leads to overly cautious save spamming and kinda kills the fantasy art vibe.

Game looks cool, very nice art, story seems compelling. But I don't want to be annoyed while playing a game by tedious stuff that should have been ironed out by the devs.

132606415.review:
Just play the Definitive Edition instead, it has both beautiful gameplay and quality of life features. This only has beautiful gameplay.

From a completionist's mindset, this game is such a nightmare. It might just a case of bad luck, but I've had to restart on multiple occasions due to certain items not appearing on the map even though I have upgrades specifically for revealing said items. The way the game determines whether an area has 100% completion is also quite nonsensical as it does not count life and energy cells as percentages. But most frustratingly (and I say this because it was such an avoidable problem; see Definitive Edition) is the fact that some areas become inaccessible as the story progresses, meaning there's no way to grab items you've previously missed.

Anyhow, my frustrations are [i] absolutely [/i] influenced by recency bias. Just enjoy Definitive Edition instead; the Ori games are such a wonderful treat!

----
-Visual (Pro)
I'm not a platformer type of player, but the artwork is so refined that it makes you forget its a 2D game.

-Music  (Pro)
Play this with headphones. Bravo to sound designers.

-Plot (Pro)
Although the plot is relatively simple, it was so much richer than I expected for a platformer. The story told in a way that you actually care. Some portions are even emotional.

-Performance
I don't care about 'Frames Per Second' and '8K Graphics' - My appreciation of a game revolves around gameplay, story and art.

130157863.review:
Ori and the Blind Forest is a critically acclaimed side-scrolling platformer with beautiful graphics, an engaging story, and tight gameplay. It follows the journey of Ori, a small white guardian spirit, and Sein, a spirit of light, as they try to restore the balance of the forest of Nibel.

One of the standout features of the game is its stunning visual design, with hand-painted backgrounds and smooth, fluid character animations. The game's soundtrack is equally impressive, with a sweeping and emotional score that perfectly complements the action on screen.

In terms of gameplay, Ori and the Blind Forest offers a challenging yet fair experience, with a variety of abilities and power-ups to unlock as you progress through the game. The controls are responsive and the platforming is tight, making for an enjoyable experience overall.

Overall, Ori and the Blind Forest is a must-play for fans of the side-scrolling genre and anyone who appreciates a well-crafted game with a compelling story and beautiful visuals. It is a strong foundation for the franchise and has set a high bar for future entries to live up to.

125010841.review:
This game just blew my mind - astounding platformer, probably the best I've played since GB/NES times.

I've started this game on the desktop and put it aside but once I got my steam deck I gave it another shot and finished the game after several sessions.

Where to start:
* 10/10 music and sounds
* 10/10 graphics
* 10/10 control & movement concept
* 10/10 Steam deck integration
* 5/10 story telling (text boxes)
* 2/10 synchronization for characters

# pros 

There is a constant build-up in what ori can do, like double jump, different fight moves, dashing and so on. The main focus is survival, not getting hit, not jumping into the void or thorns or lava.

I also liked that most of the story is not communicated by dialog but cut-scenes.

Loved the boss fights, loved the dungeons, loved the swimming concept and especially the fighting and frequent dying was rather well designed. Never felt like having to wait too long or doing the same stuff twice - this is in total contrast to games like Mega man, Super mario games from GB/NES/SNES era.

There are so many little parts in the map you can't visit at first, but when you come back later there is some power-up or story element to discover. Assisted by a wonderful minimap.

The soundtrack is just amazing and embeds seamlessly into the game world. The sounds are well designd and I did not find a single thing I did not like. The music was what drove me to ORI in the first place.

Same goes for the graphics, the Steam Deck did have perfect 60 FPS while remaining cold - low power usage. There was not a single issue with the proton emulation of the game either, except, suspend&resum cycle triggered an audio stutter where one has to restart the game.

# cons

The story itself is very good, love all the different districts the game visits, characters and especially animations. Where ori falls a bit short is the synchronization, which is keept cross-country, but for me it killed the immersion. Instead I would love a native speaker, instead of a text-bubbles with the foreign language speaker. Nintendo does this universal language stuff in their modern Switch games also which really annoys me. 
I loved the way the text bubbles were rendered into the level tough, just amazing!

# summary

Get this game, play it on the steam deck or switch, it is just amazing!!!

Hope more developers would create their games in this way. I'd imagine a Mega man adaption of this concept.

124433972.review:
If you want a fun, one-off metroidvania with a touching story, great graphics and fluid movement, this is the game to try. But this review isn't about that, it's about the hell that is "getting all achievements in ORi and the Blind Forest".
To start with the biggest problem of all: Even though the game looks beautiful, the performance is attrocious so you have to turn down your graphics to the point where it looks like a blocky pixel game from the 90s, thus making one of its good values irrelevant.
Second of all, the movement, while fluid, has inconsistencies, especially when it comes to wall jumps. Some surfaces are jagged in the weirdest ways and your character just slips off them and falls into spikes. Said spikes usually have weird hitboxes and deal a lot of damage so getting a couple life orbs or being absolutely perfect feels mandatory for any deathless attempts
Speaking of which, the game is not at all suited for deathless runs, nor many other achievements it has on Steam. All lasers kill you instantly, regardless of your hp, making some platforming sections horrendous. There even are enemies who shoot lasers and you can probably guess how much fun you're going to have with those. Lack of consistency, poor performance and occasional lag spikes don't help the overall flow. 
The achievement for finding all secrets is bugged and sometimes doesn't update despite finding a new secret. The map sometimes doesn't show collectibles even if you buy upgrades that should make them visible on it.
The gliding mechanic has weird hiccups when you tap the glide button. Tap gliding is required in a couple tight tunnels if you don't want to smash your face against a spike, and the hiccups make it annoyingly difficult.
In this version you can't teleport anywhere, making backtracking a chore and you can't access some core story-related areas after leaving them (the "dungeons") so if you miss a life cell or some percentage of the map revealed, you need to start over or constantly make backup saves

Most of these problems are fixed in the Definitive Edition, so if you want to have fun with the game, I recommend buying that one, but even DE isn't free of many of the mistakes that this game has in store. The final area, which is the most annoying, poorly-designed hellscape I've seen in a while, is untouched, and just as tedious in DE as it is in this here vanilla version.

Made a bet with a friend to get all achievements, I regret ever agreeing on that. Definitely not one of our brightest ideas

124423270.review:
If you haven't played this masterpiece of a series, you should. There are plenty of positive reviews on the page already so i'll skip that. This game is not completionist friendly, so if you are one, hide this version and play the Definitive Version (which was released to fix the below mentioned problems) or prepare for some mental damage. 

1. There is no teleportation feature. Backtracking from one end to another is your only option in the game if you missed something.
2. There is no dash (not a really big deal if you don't mind running from places to places, also speedrunning is an achievement in the game).
3. Achievements in this game can be quite glitchy to properly obtain.
4. Some major-plot areas become locked after you finish, no backtracking to loot stuff you missed.
5. Once you finish the game on a playthrough, you can't enter that save file again to get 100%.
6. Terrible performance on low graphics + game has a lot of bugs.
7. Combat is... just mashing a button.

120862818.review:
It's obvious that this game was a labor of love. Everything, from the meticulously drawn backdrops to the incredible soundtrack to the genuinely moving story, is made with such attention to detail and raw passion that you feel like you're playing a Pixar movie. It's a Metroidvania, but not a super hardcore one; navigation and the various abilities you acquire are pretty straightforward and don't require hours of practice to master. However, the game is a bit on the linear side. There's just not a lot of side stuff to do unless you want to go collectible hunting for max stats. Also, the little escape sequences after you finish a dungeon can be somewhat unforgiving since they're timed, but I thought they were a fun change of pace.

I recommend the game just for the visuals and music alone, but the game in its entirety is highly enjoyable.

Overall:
-Movement mechanics 4/10 early game, 9/10 late game
-Art 10/10
-Story 5/10

Details:
-Movement mechanics are only fun later in the game as you gain more and more movement abilities. In the beginning the movement can feel slow and hard to control (the full jump is animated and you have a bit of hang time). Towards the end of the game after you've gained all abilities sometimes it can get confusing, or you may accidentally activate certain abilities. I do not think the key controls were well selected for these different movements.
-Focus is not on combat (you usually spam attacks), but instead on movement and parkour.
-The boss fights are actually escape sequences.
-Art is gorgeous.
-Many people like the story but I wasn't super impressed with it.

200g self-raising flour
1 ½ tsp baking powder
1 tbsp golden caster sugar
3 large eggs
25g melted butter, plus extra for cooking
200ml milk
vegetable oil, for cooking

This is how you do it

STEP 1
Mix 200g self-raising flour, 1 ½ tsp baking powder, 1 tbsp golden caster sugar and a pinch of salt together in a large bowl.

STEP 2
Create a well in the centre with the back of your spoon then add 3 large eggs, 25g melted butter and 200ml milk.

STEP 3
Whisk together either with a balloon whisk or electric hand beaters until smooth then pour into a jug.

STEP 4
Heat a small knob of butter and 1 tsp of oil in a large, non-stick frying pan over a medium heat. When the butter looks frothy, pour in rounds of the batter, approximately 8cm wide. Make sure you don’t put the pancakes too close together as they will spread during cooking. Cook the pancakes on one side for about 1-2 mins or until lots of tiny bubbles start to appear and pop on the surface. Flip the pancakes over and cook for a further minute on the other side. Repeat until all the batter is used up.

STEP 5
Serve your pancakes stacked up on a plate with a drizzle of maple syrup and any of your favourite toppings.

118247665.review:
Words simply can't describe what a beautiful game this is, developer Moon Studios really poured their heart and soul into this game and the end results show.
Graphically, the game is just stunning, with colors running the gamut of the rainbow and the backgrounds teeming with detail to make the land of Nibel come to life. It's a literal example of the "Games as Art" trope and that is not a bad thing, it looks like a moving painting and easily rivals the best of what Japanese developer Vanillaware has to offer. Simply put, this game is one of the best looking action platformers. It's sequel eclipses it that much more. Story wise, without giving away too much spoilers, you play as Ori, a character whose unique appearance belies explanation, but whose story starts off with tragedy. Ori begins their journey to explore the Nibel where the balance of light and dark has gone awry, and finds out what their destiny is. The story is explained in vignettes scattered throughout the game as you progress further within. Fun fact: Ori is a name that means "My Light" in Hebrew, fitting since the character you play is literally a being of light. Gameplay wise, it's a Metroidvania, meaning that you are playing through a large, labyrinthine maze that is all connected to a central hub, fighting creatures using your abilities that you have, and yes, you end up gaining more abilities as the game progresses through fighting enemies to gain what are known as ability points, which is a mechanic used to grant Ori, the game's titular main character, new abilities that help them progress throughout.
All in all, no matter what platform you get this game and its incredible sequel on, you're in for a treat all around. Ori and the Blind Forest is one of those rare gems that is just stunning to look at and an absolute joy to play once you master the mechanics given to you throughout. So I will simply say, get this game.

116178380.review: A beautiful game. The art direction is done very well and makes for a beautiful but dark forest you must restore to let it breathe light and life again. It’s an environmental theme. I’m not crazy about puzzle side scrollers but this one had some interesting approach, of essentially motion puzzles. The combat is untraditional where you can use vectors to redirect enemy fire at you, or a number of other unique and fun ways. There is a joy to be found in floating through the sky and jumping around as swiftly as Ori, being a small creature of light that must use its wits not brute strength to survive in a dangerous and hostile forest. I found it reminiscent of James Camron’s Avatar and even the other Avatar the Last Airbender where it concerns restoring balance to the elements of the world. I found parts of the game to be quite challenging and requiring many tries, even from a Dark Souls player. The atmosphere of this game is something to marvel at times. A solid game, even if parts of it made challenge rage. 8/10

113742373.review:
So. I have to be honest.

I absolutely love the story, atmosphere, visuals and audio of this game.

However. It has some pretty major downsides that make it hard to truly enjoy the experience and story of the game.


First off. In areas where enemy projectiles is needed to use the bash ability, the enemies are unreliable in firing their projectile in a useful rate of fire.

Second. I really hate the major increase in difficulty in the Element of Light escape sequences. They are incredibly unforgiving and terribly unbalanced.

If it was possible, i really would appreciate a patch that would alter the gameplay in those sequences to adapt to the players style or let them make a save in safe zones.


Alll in all. These downsides is a major detriment to the otherwise amazing game, which is a shame, as i would love to play it to completion, but because of them, i doubt i ever will be able to by standard means.


Do i recommend the game?

That depends on the players skill at handling gameplay that require highly precise movement, timing and memory of the path through the sequences.

If its someone that can, then yes. If not, i advice to be ready for alot of potential frustration.


Either way, in terms of the story, visual and audio, i can recommend considering buying the game, but to be ready for alot of difficulty progressing in the game.

It's much easier on the PC. Would recommend you watch how many saves you use or else you may get stuck in an area that is too difficult for you to pass through. If you're a huge fan of platforming games like hollow knight, then this is another beautiful game for you to try out! Very fun to speedrun as well if you're interested in doing so! Unplayable punishing platform game.

People love it initially because it's shiny and pretty, but look at how few players finish it. 
You will get stuck and stuck and stuck and finally give up.

I've tried both this and the newer "definitive version" and the problems are identical.

You never know where you're supposed to go or even where you can go, which wouldn't necessarily be bad on its own, but:
The game must be played in a specific order.
Everything looks the same. The art style is beautiful, but there are no unique areas to explore.
You can't always tell what's background and what's part of the game. You don't know what's a path and what isn't, what you can jump onto, what will block you, what will hurt or kill you.
The above I could live with to enjoy the magical imagery, but the platforming is frustration hell, no matter your difficulty setting, and when you encounter one you can't pass, that's it, you're done. You won't even get to see most of the game.

[h1]This game has accessibility issues for players that need, or prefer to use controllers.[/h1]

The controls are very unbalanced. If you want to play this game, don't use joystick controllers, this game demands a D-pad or keyboard. The slightest wrong nudge of the stick makes this game misfire input, even if it's by a few degrees and not a direct downward turn, aiming side to side will trigger the response.

110366602.review:
While it largely teaches by example in the 2nd dramatic 'escape' sequence there are too many similar falling shapes. Rhombus shaped stalactites - possibly formed of ice - that damage you. Large boulders of different shapes with different shaped stalactites that instantly kill you but these are mixed together in both the fore and background. The first 'escape' sequence had water rushing beneath you but the vibration felt somewhat appropriate. But in the 'wind' escape sequence it's just a constant uninformative painful shake that seems determined to undermine your control. I stopped playing it halfway through because I stopped feeling like the game would be fair.

Okay I got a stubborn streak I guess - I did complete it. The chase sequences are very cinematic in their own way but I will have to check to see if they feature in the sequel before I play it. I think this game was trying to be Nintendo hard but has a degree of 'fuzziness' on ledges and far too many ledges had unnecessary spikes. It would have been fine in a 'speed test' or 'hard' mode but by the time I got to the games conclusion after spending so long on the final sequence I wasn't in a good mood and that made me overly critical instead of empathetic. 

The games plots too confusing for me to recommend. Unless you are a dedicated fan of platformer genres who wants a challenge over narrative you probably won't enjoy this game.

One of the kindest games I've ever played. I didn't know that just a computer game can give a feeling of hope and amazing bright joy. The story is absolutely wonderful, although it seems one-sided at first… Which is completely wrong, of course. The plot is well constructed and reveals itself gradually. And yes, I cried at the end like many people here. Cried again when 
retold the plot everyone who asked for it :)

The graphics are also amazing, the game is insanely beautiful. You can make a screenshot at any time, and it will be good, I have sent such a lot to friends, because it is impossible not to share such beauty. And it's also interesting that the game is built in 2D format, when you can't look at the picture from above or below. I have rarely seen such games drawn so colorfully and in detail.

The mechanics of the game are simple, but the mechanics are not the main thing here. The fighting is easy, mostly you need to jump and climb. At the same time, I was almost never bored doing it, because everything is built in the form of riddles, which become more and more complicated over time. I even had to turn to YouTube a couple of times, because I couldn't decide for myself…

Overall I highly recommend this game. One of the best I've met, if you sum up all the characteristics.

107507399.review:
Ori and the Blind Forest is a beautiful game. Absolutely gorgeous visuals, and the score is fantastic. If videogames are a form of art, then Ori is a masterclass in aesthetics. The animation is fluid, the colour schemes are gorgeous, and the character silhouettes are perfect.

The mood was touching, with the cutscenes and music playing together to evoke the emotions the devs wanted you to feel, and the storyline's conclusion is sharp, but lovely.

Gameplay wise, I had some issues with it. I had to play it with a keyboard and mouse and the amount of wrong inputs caused many a death. A lot of the collision on the spikes in particular seemed a little off, and enemy attacks and Ori's attacks often covered each other to the point you couldn't adjust in time.

My biggest issue was the escape sequences. The rubber banding in the water level made double jumping awkward, and you basically had to execute the entire sequence flawlessly by memory, rather than reacting to objects coming up. The difficulty levels are somewhat unbalanced.

However, the powerups are interesting, and the utility tree helped make the last sections slightly easier. Some of the abilities themselves could have been adjusted to streamline movement, but for the most part they worked with the platforming aspect.

Overall I enjoyed the visuals, the music, the story, and the general mood and environmental storytelling. The beginning levels and finding collectibles was fun, but the later half of the game was irritating and I came close to quitting entirely. 

I recommend it for the aesthetics, but not for casual players who aren't in the mood for constant resets, or if precise movement is difficult to manage.

В первую очередь хочется отметить графику и музыкальное сопровождение - они тут выше всяких похвал, несмотря на то, что это 2D. Не припомню ни одного платформера, где была проделана настолько кропотливая работа с фоном, анимацией, цветом и светом. Саундтрек уже стал культовым и с первых нот уже трогает до глубины души.

Сюжет в игре тоже заслуживает высшую оценку. Несмотря на яркие краски игры, история наполнена грустью. Она не отличается большой глубиной и неожиданными сюжетными поворотами, но при этом вызывает бурю эмоций, заставляет переживать всем персонажам, даже, на первый взгляд, отрицательным. Концовка очень трогает.

Я прошел игру на геймпаде. Игра сложная, местами прям очень. Умирать приходится часто, благо тут можно сохраниться практически в любом месте в любое время. Да и вообще система сохранений сделана очень грамотно и органично вписана в геймлей. Игровых механик для платформера очень много, они очень разнообразные и все очень понравились: тут и игры с гравитацией, и прыжки по врагам и их снарядам, и дерево прокачки. В общем, геймплей очень интересный.

Однозначно советую Ori and the Blind Forest всем!

105353080.review:
TLDR: That’s going to be a 10 from me dawg.

The mechanical aspect of Ori is one of the finest I've experienced in a video game. The platforming is brilliant. Ori controls perfectly. Movement is tight, but the motion is fluid. The translation of what your hands are doing and what you see on the screen is so intuitive. The pure kinetic joy of moving around the world of this game makes it so hard to put down.

All of these most basic strengths of Ori is what makes the game so enjoyable since it feeds into the other aspects of the game. It makes exploring the whole map and going after the collectibles fun because no matter how far anything is that you want to get to, you don't mind going there since the journey to that destination as you jump, dash, and run through the world is so enticing. And no matter how many times you die trying to accomplish a section of the game, you keep on doing it because it's challenging fun.

The level design in particular is marvelous. How the platforms are placed and spaced, both the static parts and moving parts and how the enemies are designed and carefully positioned in the map... all of that feels purposefully done.

Then there are these "escape" sections, Indiana Jones-esque sequences which are perfect for giving you that slight burst of adrenaline. There's a part where you run away from a huge boulder. Another part where you run away from rushing lava. But the absolute highlight in this respect is the escape from the Ginzo Tree, which was such a rush.

While the game design is one thing, how the abilities are designed to enable Ori to interact with this world is equally brilliant.   You're presented with so many well made sections for platforming and puzzle solving, then you're also given a swiss army knife of abilities with which to solve everything. These abilities are perfectly catered for the goal that they're supposed to help achieve, and there's no one way to solve much of this world, which makes using your abilities all the more engaging.

Besides the gameplay though, the presentation of the game is great. The visuals are amazing and are perfectly complemented by one of the best soundtracks I've heard in years. The atmosphere of the game is so delicately "zen", with gorgeously lush and colorful flora.

Finally... dem feels. My god, dem feels. Throughout the game there are only 2 characters that talk, Sein and the narrator and they both don't even talk much. The story of Ori and the Blind Forest is mostly told in vignettes, and it's a testament to this game's writing team how much an emotional punch the game delivers by saying so little. There are several sequences that are especially heartwrenching, but every little touch in this very simple story is just enough to tug at those heartstrings. The game touches on themes of love, kindness, and friendship so clearly that it's sad to leave these characters by the end.

Everything is simply a triumph. I can't think of anything bad to say about Ori and the Blind Forest. I literally can't. I was so consumed by how fun it was to control Ori and use Ori's abilities. I was enthralled by how enjoyable it was to move Ori through this world that was so well designed. And throughout the whole experience, I was also emotionally driven by this brilliantly imagined world, with the music, visuals, and story all coming together to support how good the game is. Please give it a try.

102768336.review:
I just finished the game and I gotta say: Even though it is a relatively short game, I really enjoyed it! The visuals are stunning and the music is a masterpiece on its own. But I think you already gathered that from the other reviews, the reason I wanted to write a review myself is to add some nuance into the mix. 

First of all, I play games who have generally very tight controls (take hollow knight for example). This game's controls have a more "floaty" feeling which I had to get used to. It feels like the controls are less tight (but in reality they are, just keep that in mind). But don't get me wrong, once you get the hang of it, the movement feels incredible and is visually very pleasing.

As I said the visuals are stunning but can also be confusing at times. Background or enemies that are unintentionally obscured by foreground, not always clear indicators of what to do in certain places etc. I guess this is a compromise they had to make but it can lead to frustration.

Speaking about frustration: the escape sequences... I find those in my humble opinion very frustrating. Sure they are beautiful (like everything in this game) but they are not really about skill but more so about trial and error (unless you have really fast reflexes I guess). The trial and error part would not be so bad if you did not have to start from the beginning when you die. Some sequences are really long and require almost near perfection to complete. That all said: the pay-off when you complete such a sequence is incredible. I could feel my adrenaline rushing when everything was settled down. 

My final point is that the game is fairly linear for a metroidvania. Sure new paths open up by acquiring new abilities but they are relatively limited and sometimes even meaningless. No fast travelling is available which can be annoying at times: To give an example, you can reach the final mountain of the game pretty early on by following a long path dashing from enemy to enemy. It was a disappointment to reach the final place only to find out that I needed a key to open it. All the way back I went ... the game has several of those moments where it lets you advance pretty far, only to find out that it is still a bit too early to come there, further discouraging exploration. I am not sure if this was intentionally or not but if you use your abilities creatively you can get to places you did not think you could reach. Also, upon completing the game I was not able to explore the world in more detail because your save file gets locked, again discouraging exploration.

As a conclusion, I really recommend that you give this game a try. The game has some interesting new concepts to offer (which are really satisfying), beautiful art, beautiful music and a very nice atmosphere. Overall it is a great experience with only some minor issues. 8/10 

PS: I have not played the definitive edition yet so I do not know if some chances were introduced that solved some of my issues with this game. However, from what I have seen the issues remain the same. Just keep that in mind.

101826782.review:
[h1] I copy and pasted my upcoming Review from the Definitive Edition, since they're literally the same game but the Definitive Edition offers you a few more things. What exactly? This: [/h1]

NEW IN THE DEFINITIVE EDITION
• Packed with new and additional content: New areas, new secrets, new abilities, more story sequences, multiple difficulty modes, full backtracking support and much more!
• Discover Naru’s past in two brand new environments.
• Master two powerful new abilities – Dash and Light Burst.
• Find new secret areas and explore Nibel faster by teleporting between Spirit Wells.

Review:

Ori and the Blind Forest is good, but the comparisons to other classic side-scrollers are erroneous because Ori is too simple and unoriginal to withstand the test of time. There are many decades old games that are still better platformers than Ori. It’s ironic how developers who more than likely grew up playing Castlevania: SOTN and Duck Tales can’t create a game that topples their places as some of the best side-scrollers ever. This is tragic since Ori was developed over 5 years by a multinational team. It also shows how stagnant the gaming industry has become. When 20+ year old games are still considered the best in their genres, the future looks a bit glum for gamers.

After playing a few hours, I noticed Ori suffers from many of the same flaws seen in the today’s bestselling games. First, Ori’s mechanics panders to gamers. Players only need to spam a button to attack. Death is hardly inconvenient because players can create spawn points. Objective markers guide players to their destinations. The story isn’t bad and it was a lot of fun to play the 7 hours.

Second, Ori’s emphasis is on visuals. Sure, Ori is pretty. But the platforming component—which is supposedly the heart of this game—is lackluster. Controlling the teensy creature is challenging enough without having to precisely land it on microscopic surfaces. Even on a 32” screen, Ori is tiny. On the whole, the critter performs like a wet eel which results in an inordinate amount of frustration. Excellent visuals are trumped by imprecise controls. But numerous other decisions, such as bland map design and cheap deaths mar what could’ve been one of the best gaming experiences in a while but with that... its just "cool" or "good".

Third, difficulty is often contrived. Ori is a die-to-learn type of game. The developers intended for players to die, frequently. Many of these deaths result from Ori’s imprecise controls. Other times players have to take leaps of faith because the path forward isn’t clear. This happens a lot. And some sequences are just damn frustrating. I’ve read complaints by gamers who died 12+ times completing specific sections. Their complaints stem from radical difficulty spikes. Ori’s difficulty spikes from a 5 to 15 in certain areas. Some deaths are just cheap since players have absolutely no chance of reacting to invisible traps. Difficulty should increase organically, something the best platformers do right. Cheap deaths are…well…cheap. And Ori has too many “gotcha” moments. Ori muddles the distinction between challenging and fun.

Fourth, Ori suffers from poor level design. Progression is often hindered because hidden traps or overly difficult trial-and-error sequences stump players. Like the original Megaman games, Ori relies too much on memorization at times. And those games are notoriously tough to beat. Backtracking doesn’t feel natural. That is a bit counter-intuitive for this style game. Its "good" as well don't get me wrong but it could be so much better.

Last, Ori is short. People reported completing it in 6 or less hours just after release. Players who’ve taken longer the complete Ori mentioned their insanely high death counts. I read one player died 436 times. That’s ridiculously high. Some of the numbers were high enough to make Dark Souls look easy in comparison. Basically, a decent gamer can complete Ori in 6-7 hours. A less skilled gamer or someone not acclimated to platformers could spend considerably more time. This additional time is attributed to unfair design.

Underneath its pleasing aesthetics, Ori is an average / maybe "mostly positive" platformer. It’s exemplifies how terrible current games really are when a mundane, but pretty, platformer is given such rave reviews. If I would rate it I would give it a 7.5 out of 10 since the Game is overall enjoyable but the "Chase sequences" after each "temple" are hardly trial and error and at this moment its not "hard" its just "frustrating" to die and learn that what you did was wrong and you need to do the whole sequence again...

101252853.review:
Quick:

5/5.  It feels great to play and review a game that actually lives up to the hype.  For so long, I avoided playing through the Ori series.  Part of the reason for my abstinence, was skepticism about the high praise the game was getting.  I saw several reviews and glimpsed at a few playthroughs here-and-there for a few years, and never got enough motivation to dive in and see what all the fuss was about.  How I have wasted my time.  This game is amazing.   I wish I played it sooner, and was able to take part in experiencing it for the first time with the rest of the world.  I love this game.


More:

Ori and the Blind Forest is great.  That is simple and accurate enough praise to loosely capture the experience of playing it... yet there is so much more to it.  I thought that I had the general idea of what the game was before I played it.  Yet, I was wrong.  The artwork, the music, the story... I had heard all about them.  The experience of it, however... the sum of all of its parts... was something else entirely. 

If you've heard anything about it, then you have probably heard about the artwork.  This game is gorgeous.  Even 6 years after its release, the timeless visuals, attention to detail, and unique character designs still look amazing and fresh.  A true spectacle, captivating and enchanting to behold, Ori evokes a sense of wonder and amazement while immersing you in a colorful, dangerous, and deep world.

The soundtrack is second to none.  If you love atmospheric music, then you will love the soundscape here.  While traversing the world, there are slow and soft piano melodies, accented with strings, and perhaps wind instruments.  I am not a musician, but I know a good tune when I hear it.  I'm almost certain that I am not accurately conveying the grandiosity of the soundtrack in this review... nor can I.  Just play the game.

Ori starts the journey as most things do... very small.  The game opens with a respectably long cinematic, which does a great job to get you invested.  Granted, it's not the best, or most unique story around, but it does a perfectly good job ushering you into the world on the other side of the title screen.  I did feel a bit disappointed after the opening.  I had a lot of questions, and I felt confused about what exactly was happening... however my understanding was more than sufficient to get the journey started.  After finishing the game, I really have no complaints about the story and how it began.  However, when I started, there was a feeling of doubt.

You meet lots of cool customers along your way through this world.  I did not see one enemy, or character design that I did not like.  This game definitely has its own 'feel' to it, and you can tell that the design team were all on the same page, or at least really vibing together when they were working on this.  I truly felt like I was in another world while I was playing this game.  So much so... that I just had to go back.

It goes without saying... the game isn't perfect... because, no game is.  No game can be perfect.  If a game is perfect... it's probably because the person scoring it is the same person that made it.  I'm sure there are people who think this is perfect.  I wouldn't even attempt to argue with them about that.  I'm sure there are also people who think this game is horrible (those people, however, I would give a verbal jabbing).  I had my fair share of vocal outbursts and heavy criticism while playing through this.  There were times when I thought that I absolutely hated this game.  Those times were when my progression was halted due to what I consider to be poor design.  It happened often enough that it did leave a bad taste in my mouth about the overall experience, yet it pales in comparison to everything else that Ori is, so much so, that it is almost not worth mentioning.  If I told someone that a glass marble that I was holding was a perfect sphere... and they broke out their laser micrometer to prove to me that it wasn't... then I would just agree to disagree.  I don't think Ori is perfect... because there are some parts that seem non-intuitive, and almost mean from a design perspective.  Some parts of this game appear as if they have been designed to be frustrating, hard to understand and predict, or that the designers wanted the players to fail / wanted the game to be more difficult.  Those times, though frustrating beyond belief, are to Ori and the Blind Forest what a microscopic scratch on a glass marble is to its overall 'roundness'.  

In the grand scheme of things, the problems with Ori and the Blind Forest are strangely inconsequential and monumentally frustrating at the same time.  So much of this game is amazing, that those problems become microscopic in comparison.  I cannot remember the last time that I loved a game that caused me so much pain.  Ori and the Blind Forest is a perfect example of a something being perfectly-imperfect.  That is a phrase that I hate to use, yet it exists because of phenomenon like this.  

I love this game.

99898197.review:
If I could sum this game up in one word: frustrating. 
The game is very beautiful but the art direction gets in the way of the gameplay. I had a lot of trouble discerning enemy attacks (green, purple, orange) from my attacks (white), as well as the orbs received from killing enemies (yellow). I also had trouble discerning hazards and platforms from the foreground and background. I died a lot. I spent some time gathering health orbs but it doesn't really matter, there are plenty of insta-kill hazards scattered around. So I saved often. However, you can't save during boss sequences so I ended up doing the same sequences over a dozen times. The tension disappears after so many tries, turning the game into a slog with the same bland repetitive music playing throughout (I found the music to be forgettable). Ori's little death gasps became a droll metronome.  
The story is literal nonsense, you're a leaf from the spirit tree that fell off in a windstorm and this somehow kills nearly everything in the forest. The narrator (the spirit tree) intones "OOOba DAAba DOOba" over every cutscene, explaining how you (Ori) are important to restoring the light (but not too much light?) to the land, with a secondary expository NPC (Sein) explaining in detail all the McGuffins you're fetching or turning on. It doesn't matter at all: all you need to know is an owl hates you. 
The one interesting mechanic which actually made the game fun would be the "Dash" mechanic, where you can get close to a projectile and press a button to dodge/boost in a direction, while the projectile goes in the other direction. This is used effectively for some fun mechanics, but I sometimes had trouble figuring out which projectiles enemies were "dash-worthy": you can't use dash on everything. 
If you're looking for a platforming challenge, I'd like to recommend Celeste. If you're looking for a good Metroidvania, I'd recommend Symphony of the Night, Carrion, or Super Metroid. 
But maybe you'll love this game, all I can tell you is I felt relief upon finishing and don't feel the need to ever play again.

99836711.review:
Ori and the blind forest is a game for those whom are seeking a challenging game with a beautiful story.
As someone who usually avoids game's focused on jumping puzzle mechanics i decided to give this game that had been sitting in my library a chance and i was very please with the game a a whole though with only a single issue.
The story was brilliant and paired with its art style and minimal voice acting brought a certain emphasis to the music helping it create a emotional pull for the player that draws you in to get lost in the story and makes you want to see what happens next.
The change of gameplay was interesting and challenging but the single issue i have with it was the fact that you cannot replay and explore once you finish the main story so be cautious if you wish to 100% each map do it before moving on to the next part of the story as some will become locked after you leave.

In total if you are looking for a change in gameplay that will challenge you and give you a good shorter story than usual Ori and The Blind Forest is a great game to pick up and play for a while.

96969068.review:
This game is still as wonderful as the first time I had played it, and it is one of my favorite games.  

It has a beautiful storyline that is easy to follow and leaves very little unanswered.  Ori's journey through the world to bring life back to everything is heartening, but I also love Kuro.  At the beginning she was painted as this terrible being that brought famine and darkness into the land, but the story does bring to light why she acts the way she does.  The final achievement before the game completes is my favorite because it demonstrates that love conquers all, and that is a very powerful lesson to teach, especially with a younger audience.  

The soundtrack beautifully demonstrates all of the emotions going through each of the areas of the game, from the scenery to the chase scenes.  I couldn't think of any better way to compose the soundtracks for each of the sections of the game.  I have purchased the soundtrack both physically and digitally so I can listen to it wherever I can.  

The achievements are also very plausible and give harder ones for people that are achievement hunters and like the challenge in games.  While I am one of those people, I personally thought the Find All Secrets achievement was really difficult.  I played through the game 3 times and I still couldn't get all the secrets to trigger so I could get the achievement.  However, I do realize those are for the people that want the challenge, and the game is otherwise perfect and wonderful.

Overall, I absolutely would recommend playing the game (please do play the original first and then the Definitive Edition since there is added content) and then playing Will of the Wisps~  20/10

95810612.review:
Start to end a masterpiece.

The visuals are incredible and the soundtrack is outstanding, both are a show apart. Beautiful cutscenes. I have to put this game's OST in my top3 OSTs for sure. The OST is very fitting to the elements, therefore very immersive.

The plot is pretty good. It's objective, no stalling and the ending is very wholesome. I love all of it.

Fun gameplay, the classic metroidvania formula, the world is well designed to favor Ori's skills. It has a great variety of scenarios that never stop to shine. And plus, this game has challenge, particularly Mount Horu and the Forlorn Ruins were pretty difficult. It has a very decent puzzle solving aspect to it, you have to think a bit to get through some challenges.

I admit I thought in the beggining that by having only one way of directly attacking (early-game) the game would get too mashy, but the game has some attacking method variety that are later unlocked and as well provides you upgrades to skills and attacks, making them stronger and allowing them to hit more enemies at once, so that prevents the game from getting too reliant on spamming. Other than that, skills will give you more mobility and it'll be possible to find more secrets. In the start it can be hard to get the hang of it, but it gets easier to get around the more the game goes through.

It's a grand game, literally, the map is huge, tons of places to explore. Due to this reason, getting to a side to another takes forever, you have to stay tuned to the map all the time to go through several branches and splitting paths.

However, it's a game I consider to be short, you can finish it under 10 hours and get a 100% in 13. The 100% is not very demanding, I even got 99% of all in my first try in 13 hours! It gives me a "want more" sensation, but I ain't gonna complain about that. I enjoyed every second of this game and I recommend to every single person out there. This is top3 in my favorite games list.

After you're done with the game, there's barely anything to do except for trying to 100%. Other than that, the game ends there for true. It's very elegible to a quick replay, though.

Plot: 9
Gameplay: 10
Visuals: 11
Soundtrack: 11
Fun: 10
Replay value: 6

OVERALL: 10/10

95373449.review: Ori and the Blind Forest is a visually stunning game with a beautiful original soundtrack that really makes you feel at home in this wondrous world. Overall I had a great time and the game's certainly very enjoyable when you're just going for a casual run! Great enemy variety, the different areas are all very pleasing to look at and fun to explore and of course the abilities you unlock along the way are really fun to use. My biggest issue with Ori is that after beating the last dungeon of the game you can't backtrack anymore, in fact your save file becomes useless. All you get is a save file on the menu screen saying "complete" which kinda sucks. Besides that a lot of enemies in this game just straight up one shot you, it felt more common to get one shot than to take 2-4 hits to die even with health upgrades. This isn't a massive issue until you die from one of these enemies that were off screen. Certain enemy attacks also blend into the background and forground making it hard to dodge. Ori's certainly a beautiful and well designed game but it has its flaws. I'd rate it 6.5-7/10. Some of these flaws make the 100% run and no death run very tedious but it's still a fun game!
