93147595.review:
Ori, the ever sanguine fighter to help his forest friends, and the melancholy creatures are relatable and comfortably fit in this world.
The artwork is beautiful. It plays as good as it looks.

---What is it?---
It's a platform game. You can jump around the forest and attack creatures, while running towards a place marked on your map for story reasons.
With some puzzles here and there to hinder your progress as you maneuver your way through the level.

It can be challenging, with a well thought out saving system to balance that, where you get to plant your save point yourself.

Don't let it's cute looks deceive you into thinking it will be a walk in the park. They throw every platform gimmick at you in very well thought out, beautiful and polished way. The background art changes with each new visited location, as you travel around. Upgrading your abilities as you progress, the game keeps on giving your character movements a improvement, to have a way of overcoming the new struggles ahead, until the very end.

P.S. The cards don't drop in the definitive edition, only with this one.

89363840.review:
I suck at video games. 

I feel I need to preface this with that fact. I lack the natural talent, and lack the patience to practice to make up for it. Many a difficult video game I have gotten because it was recommended and then gotten frustrated and refunded it, or just had it sit unplayed in my library forever. But this game... this one was different. 

Ori and the Blind Forest stuck with me. It carved a hollow out in my chest and just lived there. The sobbing in the first ten minutes, the gorgeous design and music, the way new abilities transformed gameplay, how awesome it felt when you pull off some feat of acrobatics, or narrowly avoid death by the skin of your teeth and sheer reflexes. 

I just finished the game tonight, after years of trying. I beat it. And now I don't know what to do with that. I guess there's a sequel, but it's not this game, the game that made me keep coming back to it until I had mastered it, the game that, for the first time in my life, made me love it so much that I had to, just had to put in the time and effort to get gud. 

Guess nothing for it but to start learning speed run strats, I guess. 

tldr: If you need me to tell you to buy this game, you aren't paying attention to the OVERWHELMINGLY POSITIVE reviews of it.

89297618.review:
It is weird to be giving this version of Ori a thumbs down, but there is good reason behind it and I wanted to write this review in hopes of maybe saving a newcomer to the franchise some heartache.  This review is specifically for vanilla Ori and the Blind Forest, as I never knew what was different in the original version versus Definitive Edition so I took a shot at this out of curiosity.  This version cannot be purchased separately anymore and is included when purchasing DE so you can't accidentally buy the wrong version, but even just 20 minutes in it becomes apparent what improvements were made in Definitive Edition.  

There is no fast travel in this game unlike DE, so you must hike everywhere at all times.  There are points of no return where you cannot return to a previously finished area in case you missed a collectible and wanted to revisit/backtrack unlike the later edition.  There are some minor bugs that exist only in vanilla and not DE, but DE is simply the better experience because DE won't ever put you in a position where full completion can become impossible if you do things out of order.  The game itself plays largely the same as DE, but there's no major point to playing vanilla unless you REALLY wanted to double down on achievements or something.  DE is simply the better game and provides much needed updates this game should have had since the beginning.

Seriously just skip this version if you think playing this first and then playing Definitive Edition is the way to go, literally just pretend vanilla isn't a thing.  I have played DE and WotW loved them both and gotten all the achievements in them, but there is a good reason this version isn't sold separately anymore.  Take my word on it and save yourself heartache of dooming your save file to a state it can't be 100% completed anymore because you did things out of order.

89292431.review:
It's a metroidvania with.... no... bosses? That's very interesting. The bosses are just obstacle course-type escape sequences that force you to use every ability you've learnt up until that point. I say 'just' because that's not typical of a metroidvania, not because it's bad. The game is phenomenal on all points.

Controls are sharp and concise. At no point did I ever feel like I died because it was the game's fault. Jump mechanics are similar to modern platformers where you can control yourself a little bit mid-flight. Combat is rather muted compared to other similar games. You will have foes but very few you need to defeat and most of which you need to take advantage of to improve your own mobility.

Graphics are as much as I'd ever want out of a side-scrolling game and the art is virtually unparalleled. Even when you're focusing on not falling in lava, you can't help but gaze at the stellar backgrounds AND foregrounds. There's nothing you don't want to look at.

The story's great, very touching and hopeful. Extremely family friendly, in fact I would recommend this to anyone of any age or walk of life. There are a few challenging spots but the general feel is, you won't get through the whole thing without dying unless you're experienced and your intent is to do an undying run.

You can save the game at any point (as long as there's no danger nearby) and are encouraged to do so during tough scenarios. There aren't any loading screens, it's all one continuous play.

I played it for the first time and beat it all in one sitting because I just couldn't stop playing. It was extremely inviting and immersive. Top marks!

88471305.review:
Ori really shows the limits of the Steam review system. I love this game, its gameplay, its fantastic mechanics, and its weird folklore. But I'm giving this a thumbs down in the hopes that someday, when I play the definitive version, I can give it the thumbs up. The original Ori, while brilliant, is too beset by the "Outlast 2" problem: chase sequences where if you fail to execute a long string of complex moves perfectly, you die. At the end of the Ginsun Tree level, I died 50+ trying to execute what are a series of tough bash moves. I'd always hit most, but even one mistake would force me to start over. That kind of trial-and-error tedium really drains me. It takes a fun game and makes it unfun.

You should get Ori, but get the definitive version and hope that some of the sequences are a little more polished and less tedious than in the original game design. There is so much to love here, but those chase sequences are enormously frustrating.

87556471.review:
Form over substance: the game.

If you can get over the usual ecolo-miyazako-sanctimonious-twaddle, you've passed the first trial. Now, you'll enjoy a bit of metroid stuff, exploring, fighting...While the first is okay, I guess (come on devs, XP to unlock skills has NOTHING to do in a metroidvania), fighting is just button smashing with a bit of dodging. Atmosphere and OST are not as bad as hollow knight but not marvelous either (awesome work, but...meh, thorns and projectiles hidden by a gorgeous background...Remember Fantasia on Genesis ? That kind of bad), 

After a few hours, you understand how awfully crafted the level design is. As a compensation, you can save anywhere, yay. Explore 50% of the game, and you are fully entering the 'super meat boy' zone. Challenge is cool when rewarding. Here ? Nope. 

At least, it is a third of the price here than it is on Nintendo Switch (talking about scam, lol)..Still hardly worth it...

87451554.review:
+ You'll get this game for free when buying Ori and the Blind Forest Definitive Edition.
+ Graphic: Beautiful
+ Music: Beautiful
+ Story: Great and emotional. Even the prologue already makes me want to cry
+ Hard and challenging, but still fair
+ Backup feature. This feature will track your last 10 saves. If something goes wrong, you can easily roll back to a previous save file

- No fast travel/teleport
- No key/controller button remapping.  
- You can't replay the game after you complete it, unless you create another separate copy/backup file before entering Mt. Horu.
- At first, there are only 3 areas that will be inaccessible after they were completed, they are Ginso Tree, Forlorn Ruins & Misty Woods. But in the end, all the other areas will also be inaccessible after you enter Mt. Horu. That makes everything in this game are missable.

Sometimes to get a secret you'll have to unlock something and come back, and without fast travel it encourages revisiting already explored areas. I recommend this game to anyone who likes exploring and platforming.

You will sit there and die again and again trying to reach another area only to fail repeatedly. it will wear on your nerves. There was one part that i was stuck on for what felt like an hour and after getting through that part, it threw me into yet another challenge that was even worse. Where do I even begin with this game? This is just a gorgeous experience of a game. But calling it a game sells it short for what it *actually is*. It's so much more than just a game that looks pretty. The game is soothing, emotional, stressful, terrifying, heart breaking, and in equal measure heartwarming. 

This is an interactive experience. Sure some of the puzzles are difficult sometimes, and the escape scenes are stressful, pushing your skills and capabilities to your limit, but it is NEVER unfair. When I've died I have known exactly why, and have grown for it. Sure, I needed multiple attempts to get it right, but it is so rewarding to get it right. No puzzle is too obsuce to not figure out after a bit of prodding.

The game's presentation, animations and the outright fantastic artwork is just wonderful. With very little dialogue the game tugs at my heartstrings with the visuals, and the animations alone. Some segments of the game look like cutscenes, but are in fact controlled by you the player. All of this comes together to tell a wonderful story about restoring the forest, with all the emotions that come with. I started the game crying, and I finished the game crying as well. The emotions that makes me cry, to me, wrapped up and tied together the whole experience. I had come full circle by the end. And I'm happier for it. This game is a cultural world heritage for what it is.

This game is in my favorites.

Ori and the Blind Forest is already quite known as one of the greatest games on Steam already, and while I've played it years ago, now that I'm taking time to try and leave a review for every game in my library, this game obviously deserves one more positive recommendation to its already overwhelming pile.

From art to gameplay, to OST, this game is a masterpiece in almost every possible way. It has some physics exploits which are still pretty difficult to perform that make it a really fun game to either speedrun or watch speedruns of. 

The biggest con, would be the story. It is in no way a bad story, nor is the writing poor or the voice acting bad. In fact, it's quite good. However, when compared to the 10/10 everywhere else, even a 8/10 can be a game's lower point.

I recommend to anyone who likes metroidvania or platformer type games. Make sure you have the sound turned up because the music is very much going to add yet another layer of enjoyment during your playthrough.

Not a bad game but the flaws are really large. The difficulty curve is not very good; the start of the game has you feeling pretty under-powered and by the end of the game you utterly steamroll everything. The game relies a lot on instant kill garbage to provide any challenge after a certain point. The gimmick of chase sequences is also not particularly fun.

Another issue is that there are at least two areas with missable collectables. Getting all the power ups is not difficult at a certain point but you can miss several and that's just incredibly poor design. Maybe the definitive version fixes it but the OG version has a big problem with it. 

Personally I found the controls to not be quite as tight as I would like. Sometimes the movement feels a bit floaty and it's easy to get killed a few times by lava or spikes during an extended sequence. The lack of checkpoints during the chase sequences is also incredibly tiresome.

83101994.review:
The game is quite fun as a platformer, brought a lot of challenge to the users, and gives me the sense of accomplishment whenever I squeeze through different challenges and difficult terrain and paths. It gives a really vibes on its music, calm and serene, the artwork, graphics, animation movements are all great, probably one of the best for platformer.
I can see the development team put a lot of efforts in the story, graphics, music and gameplay. It was really fun to play, and I got addicted to it for days before I finished the whole game.
However, the control is painful, especially for keyboard players, as my hand and fingers almost got a cramp pressing the damn glide button, I think the control is actually quite bad for a well polished game like this, sometimes you have to press it again and again in a short period of time, only to dodge the spikes and obstacles, and sometimes you have to hold as long as it can just to glide through the stream of air. It could be much better if using a controller to play this game. But it isn't so friendly to keyboard players, as the shift button is really not the best position to either hold it for a long time or pressing it repeatedly, your hands would really get screwed. I guess swapping the button assignments of bashing and gliding/climbing would be much better.
On the other hand, the game is pretty straight forward, IMO it lacks variety compared to Castlevania and Bloodstained. The monsters are pretty much the same and they don't really stand an important role in the way of your journey, just to let you bash through them to find new paths, or restoring energy or health. For me the monsters set up in the game is also very important in a platformer game, however I think this game lacks it. The game will get a bit more repetitive as it goes through the story especially mid to late game, but it is still fun as it is quite challenging. It just lacks replayability.
All in all, this game is great in many ways but some short comings are just really painful and agonising. Sometimes really make me feel like giving it up. 
Anyone who hasn't played this wonderful game should try it as soon as you can, you will fall in love straight away.
This is my first ever comment on a game on steam, just want to express my love on this game, but also share some of my concern on this game and about some of the weaknesses of it.

82290305.review:
Ori and the Blind Forest es un videojuego indie del 2015 desarrollado por Moon Studios y siendo luego adquiridos por Microsoft. Pertenece al género de los metroidvania, por lo tanto las influencias quedan claras desde el vamos, presentando características como un mapa enorme el cual será explorable poco a poco mediante la obtención de habilidades necesarias para proseguir.

La primera impresión remarcable de este título son sus efectos visuales, ya que no sólo cada entorno está cuidadísimo hasta el más mínimo detalle e interconectado con el resto sin tiempos de carga, sino que hacen gala de una animación en la vegetación y demás elementos del escenario muy fluida y suave, dando como resultado zonas que a pesar de estar en dos dimensiones se sienten vivas. Todo este trabajo en los bellos efectos visuales tuvo como inspiración las obras del mismo Hayao Miyazaki, en palabras de sus creadores.

Esto es ejemplificado muy bien por su protagonista a través de la jugabilidad. Ori es un ser pequeño de luz que se mueve a velocidades altas y con movimiento gráciles, de modo que el control debe ser muy preciso para manejarlo por los escenarios que si bien son bellos están a rebosar de peligros por todas partes, siendo muy fácil morir en demasiados puntos. Y en eso el título destaca por mucho, siendo un verdadero placer recorrer el bosque Nibel en sus extensos y bifurcados caminos los cuales guardan todo tipos de secretos que, contrario a muchos otros juegos, este título se niega a que alguno sea relleno ya que todos ellos son potenciadores que le otorgará a nuestro protagonista mejoras en salud, energía o puntos de experiencia en un muy sencillo árbol de habilidades a completar, convirtiendo así a la pequeña e indefensa criatura en una verdadera máquina de matar. Además, la rapidez de Ori al correr cobra especial importancia en esta versión, puesto que contrario a la definitiva en donde las fuentes mágicas que forman los puntos de guardado tienen la opción de teletransportarse entre ellas, aquí hay completa ausencia de dicha opción aunque no será una tarea tan engorrosa recorrer a pie el mapa como a priori puede parecer gracias a la celeridad de los movimientos del protagonista. En donde sí flaquean los escenarios es en otorgarles variación de enemigos, puesto que siempre nos enfrentaremos a los mismos tipos de monstruos con ligeros cambios lo cual les resta cierta identidad tanto a ellos como al entorno al recibir la fauna ese poco interés, contrario a su flora. El combate es, además, muy simple y limitado por lo que los enfrentamientos apenas se perciben como tal y la ausencia absoluta de jefes es una muestra inequívoca del penoso trato que recibieron los enemigos. A estos problemas se le suma la facilidad del título, porque aunque Ori puede morir sin mucho esfuerzo como se mencionó anteriormente, la capacidad que nos brinda el juego de poder guardar la partida casi donde queramos, siempre que dispongamos de un punto de energía, le resta dificultad considerablemente haciendo que despreciemos la importancia de los peligros del entorno al ser el castigo por morir regresar al último punto de guardado muy rápidamente para volver a intentarlo. Sí, el ensayo y error está presente y puede entorpecer e incluso arruinar momentos de especial importancia, problema que en la futura edición persistió y se intensificó con el añadido de los modos de dificultad, menos en el modo Una Vida donde sí que se le brinda al escenario el respeto que merece por la posibilidad de perderlo todo por un descuido.

Toda la trama narrada en Ori es tan concisa y directa que muy pronto nos pondremos en marcha a resolver el conflicto, el cual tratará de la clásica lucha de la luz contra la oscuridad con ciertos giros de tuerca en determinados puntos de la historia para justificar tanto las acciones del antagonista como las nuestras. El resto del casting, si bien es muy limitado en cuanto a cantidad y sólo uno de ellos es explorado más a fondo en la versión ampliada del juego, todos cumplen un rol importante en la historia y ya sea por sus diseños o trasfondo se les acaba cogiendo cariño. 

Sumado a todo lo dicho, la música es merecedora de recibir su propio párrafo. El trabajo de Gareth Coker es digno de aplaudir, puesto que a través de sus composiciones la música dibuja perfectamente los paisajes visuales del juego, los cuales acompañan a la perfección al diseño artístico de los escenarios dándole un uso extra para enfatizar ciertas acciones del protagonista, ya sea si encontró un secreto o recibió un poder de uno de sus antepasados, resaltando el momento con una pista corta para enfatizarlo con más fuerza. Si bien sus melodías son un tanto reminiscentes unas con las otras, destacando el leitmotiv del tema principal presente en varias de ellas y sonando especialmente en los momentos más importantes de la trama, es una banda sonora muy eficiente que sería ampliada posteriormente junto a nuevas zonas a explorar en la versión definitiva.

Ori and the Blind Forest es, a grandes rasgos, un decente metroidvania destacando por mucho su ágil jugabilidad y que si bien puede pecar de ser un poco lento y aburrido en un comienzo, no tarda mucho en abrirse en posibilidades. Sus personajes son escasos pero entrañables, y el diseño artístico junto a la banda sonora forman un juego muy bonito visualmente. Pierde fuerza por su facilidad y no inventa nada dentro del género, pero en sí es una experiencia agradable tanto para los amantes del género como para los recién llegados.

81722843.review:
Full disclosure, I haven't finished this game. I played until after the Forlorn Ruins. If it gets better after those, I sadly won't have accounted for that in this review.

I really wanted to like this game, and while there are some things it does really well, the consistent style over substance approach it takes in it's design really cause too many problems for me being able to recommend it.

The visuals are really pretty, but they do a very poor job at communicating vital information to the player. Everything is consistently flooded in blooming light effects, which oftentimes camouflages the main-character, who also is a blooming light effect. Platform edges can be hard to distinguish since the game insists on everything looking organic and unique. Which I admit, looks very nice, but it makes precision jumping unnecessarily complicated. Many platforms are unstable and swing around when jumped onto. While, again, looking pretty, this often causes problems as gaps that you are intended to jump across become too wide and you end up missing. Important visual clues like spikes are often hard to see due to these aesthetic choices as well. And speaking of spikes, Ori tends to easily get stuck in them and get hit over and over, due to the low amount of I-Frames. I honestly would have preferred instant death pits to spikes that essentially do the same, but slower.

I do like the idea of players generating their own checkpoints, but I found the implementation poor. Since creating checkpoints costs energy, you always need to consider if it's worth the cost or whether you'd rather risk pushing a little further. Since energy is also used for attacking and opening doors, it always feels punishing to create a checkpoint. It's also easy to forget about when you're starting to enjoy yourself and getting into the flow. Since this game also punishes slight missteps very harshly though, I often ended up replaying large sections due to forgetting about the checkpoint mechanic. Sure, I mostly have myself to blame for that since the tools to circumvent this are there (unless you used your energy for too many charge attacks), but I would have preferred a classic and more forgiving checkpoint system.

As for combat, that's a very mixed bag for me too. The standard weapon is an auto-aiming short range missile weapon, that unfortunately is so bright that it constantly obscures enemy projectiles and makes dodging them hard for all the wrong reasons. It's also very weak, even when upgraded, and doesn't feel fun to use at all. It gets a lot better with some of the mid-game upgrades. Charge attacks are sufficiently satisfying to use, the dash that reflects bullets is really fun, and the ground pound feels quite good too. So it can be quite satisfying, but it takes some time to get there.

One of the best parts of the game are when it allows you to go fast and string together cool stunts of aerial movement. Especially some of the later upgrades are very satisfying to use in that regard. The sequences that made heavy use of the air-dash were easily my favorite parts of the game. I am feeling some issues with how this game carries momentum, and again, the aesthetics often hinder you in making jumps with the required precision, but overall I'd say the movement is pretty good in this game.

One of the major selling points to most people seems to be the emotional story and atmosphere of this game. I don't think I am the right person to talk about this, I don't feel sad if I witness bad things happen to characters I barely even got to know first, so I found it confusing and unengaging. Important elements of the world are never explained, and the main tool to drive the plot forward seems to be "magical neon light touches things and does context-sensitive things". Since we never learn how magical neon light is supposed to work, it's left to the music to tell me how to feel, since I really can't figure out what it's supposed to do in any given scene. Also, this game thinks unskippable cutscenes are ever acceptable. Combined with the aforementioned very punishing gameplay, this has caused me a great deal of annoyance. Use your own judgement on this one. I know a lot of people liked the story, but to me it just felt like the game wanted me to feel sad for no reason.

I'm sorry, but I really can not recommend this game. In a genre that has outstanding gems like Iconoclasts, Hollow Knight and Dust, this just has too many shortcomings to be a serious contender in my book. It definitely does have it's strong points, and when it does something well it does it really well, but I just found too many annoying flaws to ever really enjoy myself for long. I sincerely hope you're having a better time with this!
